title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act adds a new section to the Internal Revenue Code, providing incentives for private land conservation. The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" offers a tax credit to eligible farmers and ranchers for conservation contributions. The credit is 10% of the deduction allowed for qualified conservation contributions, with a maximum limit of $360,000 per year. Joint filers split the credit equally. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is subject to limitations based on the amount of tax and is allocated equally between spouses on joint returns. All members of the same controlled group of corporations are treated as one taxpayer for the purposes of this credit. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited based on the amount of tax and is allocated equally between spouses on joint returns. Eligible farmers or ranchers must meet specific income criteria to qualify for the credit. The Private Land Conservation Tax Act provides a tax credit for eligible farmers or ranchers meeting income criteria. For C corporations, certain conditions must be met, including a minimum percentage of income from farming and limits on asset value. Special rules include an irrevocable election for application and restrictions on deductions for conservation contributions if the credit is taken. The Private Land Conservation Tax Act offers a tax credit for qualifying farmers or ranchers. If the credit is chosen, deductions for conservation contributions under section 170 are restricted for 15 years. Excess credit can be carried forward to the next taxable year. The Private Land Conservation Tax Act provides a tax credit for farmers and ranchers making qualified conservation contributions. The amendments in this section apply to donations made after the enactment date. SEC. 3 increases the charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form. It treats qualified farmers or ranchers as individuals for conservation contributions. SEC. 4 expands the estate tax exclusion for land under qualified conservation easements. SEC. 4 expands the estate tax exclusion for land under qualified conservation easements, with an effective date for estates of decedents dying after the enactment of the Act.
